results.title: Crane Island
results.creator_credit: Raymond Garceau, Leonard Frost and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A visit to one of the many tiny islands in the St. Lawrence River. Flocks of snow geese and other migratory birds, annually attract hundreds of sportsmen. Accompanies a party of visiting hunters as they bring down a plentiful bag. Shows the daily life of the French Canadian inhabitants who find a hardy but wholesome existence on the island’s bountiful lowland.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Raymond Garceau, Leonard Frost and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: A Cottage on Dartmoor
results.creator_credit: Anthony Asquith and British Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Released with a synchronised music disc in 1930, but essentially regarded as a silent film. Anthony Asquith last ‘silent’ film was considered a rival to Hitchcock’s ‘Blackmail’. Presents the unrequited love of a barber’s assistant for a manicurist and the results of his jealous rage when she becomes engaged to a customer, relayed in a long flash-back during his attempted escape from Dartmoor. Cast includes: Norah Baring, Uno Henning, Hans Schlettow and Judd Green. Photographed by Stanley Rodwell. Story by Herbert C. Price.

results.title: The Conductor. Pt. 1
results.creator_credit: Milton Ingerson, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A look at the art and technique of the conductor. In part one, conductor Verdon Williams discusses his role within the orchestra, use of the baton to keep rhythm; different kinds of rhythms; emphasising staccatto, accents; bringing in new instruments; starting and finishing each movement.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Milton Ingerson, Malcolm Smith and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: A Conceptual approach to teaching
results.creator_credit: Ron Saunders, Malcolm Smith, Education Dept of South Australia and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The problems presented by what is popularly called “the information explosion” are no more keenly felt than by teachers and students. This film appraises current teaching methodology and provides a basis for discussion to provoke new thoughts and ideas on teaching techniques. Designed as an in-service aid for re-assessing and re-evaluating teaching programs and methodologies and provide a starting point for curriculum development.

results.title: King Lear
results.creator_credit: Peter Brook, Michael Birkeit, Columbia, Martin Ransohoff Productions and Royal Shakespeare Company
results.brief_description: This Shakespearian tragedy tells the tale of woe when an old king decides to divide his kingdom amongst his daughters. Directed by Peter Brook and starring Paul Scofield and Irene Worth.

results.title: Colette
results.creator_credit: Yannick Bellon and Jacqueline Jacoupy Films
results.brief_description: Impressions of the life and times of Colette (1873-1954), French novelist, who probed deeply into the life of the senses and into human, particularly physical, relationships. Colette was born Sidonie Gabrielle Claudine Colette in Saint-Sauveur-en-Puisaye, Bourgogne. She collaborated with her first husband, writer Henri Gauthier-Villars on the four novels of the Claudine series (1900-1903), using his pen name (Willy); they were largely her work. Writing under the name Colette, she established her reputation as the leading woman novelist of France. She was also a journalist, critic and playwright. The film includes a short interview between Colette and Jean Creteau. Extracts from old feature films and newsreels afford glimpses of Colette when whe was a dancer in a Montmartre music hall. French language with English captions.

results.title: Coastal command
results.creator_credit: J.B. Holmes, Ian Dalrymple and Crown Film Unit
results.brief_description: This feature-length documentary film gives a dramatic account of the activities of the Coastal Command of the Royal Air Force during World War II. The organisation of the Command is seen at the control base, and the work of the Sunderland flying boats and Catalinas on patrol. The film shows a number of encounters with enemy ships, submarines and aircraft culminating in the sighting and sinking of the German raider “Bismarck” by Sunderlands of Coastal Command.

results.title: Clement Meadmore
results.brief_description: A modern sculptor in steel. This film is a plea for a sensible approach to modern art. It opens with Clement Meadmore welding a sculpture in his backyard in Sydney, followed by a survey of his works. Meadmore, who is also a leading designer in the field of fabrics and textiles, works with austere and means creating sculptures of purity of form and clarity of expression. Filmed, written and edited by Bruce Beresford. Narrated by John Bell.
